quiz.quizTitle: GCSE Triple Science: Blood, Organ, and Stem Cell Donation
quiz.summary: This quiz covers key aspects of blood, organ, and stem cell donation, aligning with GCSE Biology (OCR specification). It includes questions on the importance of donation, the types of individuals who might need donations, the processes involved in blood and stem cell donation, and the legal framework surrounding organ donation in England. The quiz features a mix of multiple-choice, short-answer, true/false, and numeric questions to assess a range of recall and analytical skills.
quiz.subject: biology
quiz.syllabusAlignment: Covers learning intentions related to the importance, steps, and legal aspects of donation, as well as individual choices.

questions.prompt: According to the provided material, approximately how many new blood donors are needed daily in England to meet demand?
questions.explanation: Page 6 states, "Nearly 400 new blood donors are needed every day in England to meet demand."

questions.prompt: Identify two types of individuals who might require an organ donation, as stated in the study material.
questions.answer: Someone whose organs have been damaged by disease or injury, or someone who has a birth defect.
questions.explanation: Page 5 lists "Someone whose organs have been damaged by disease or injury" and "Someone who has a birth defect" under 'Organ donation'.
questions.sourceReference: Page 5, "Who might need each type of donation?"

questions.prompt: How many adults can one blood donation help, according to the information provided about the blood donation process?
questions.explanation: Page 8 explains that after testing, a donor's blood is split into component parts, and "each donation can help 3 adults or 6 infants."
questions.sourceReference: Page 8, "What's involved in being a blood donor"

questions.prompt: True or False: From 2020, anyone over the age of 18 in England is automatically considered an organ donor unless they have explicitly registered a decision not to donate.
questions.explanation: Page 13 states, "From 2020, anyone over 18 in England will be considered an organ donor when they die unless they have registered a decision not to donate or are in an excluded group."
questions.sourceReference: Page 13, "Organ donation: legal changes to save more lives"

questions.prompt: Which of the following is the most common method for donating stem cells, according to the provided material?
questions.explanation: Page 10 states that "Stem cells can be donated in one of two ways: through the bloodstream (90% of donors) or bone marrow donation procedure (10% of donors)." Therefore, through the bloodstream is the most common.
options: A) Through a bone marrow donation procedure
C) Directly from umbilical cord blood
D) Via a surgical removal of lymph nodes
questions.sourceReference: Page 10, "What's involved in being a stem cell donor?"

questions.prompt: Explain two reasons why an individual might choose not to donate, based on the examples provided in the study material.
questions.answer: An individual might choose not to donate blood due to a fear of needles. Another reason for choosing not to donate organs is feeling uncomfortable with the idea of their organs being used after death, leading them to opt out on the NHS Organ Donation Register.
questions.explanation: Page 16 provides two speech bubbles illustrating reasons for not donating: "I'm really scared of needles, so giving blood isn't something I feel I'm able to do." and "I feel uncomfortable with the idea of my organs being used after I die, so I recorded my decision to opt out of organ donation on the NHS Organ Donation Register."
questions.sourceReference: Page 16, "Why do people choose not to donate?"
